Expectation1: Teaching children moral values and discipline
Situation1: The child is running around in a supermarket, and the mother needs to correct the behavior
Expectation2: Offer help or support when asked
Situation2: An acquaintance asks for assistance in moving a few boxes while moving to a new apartment.
Story: I was in the supermarket with my son, trying to keep him close as he darted between aisles, giggling and weaving around other shoppers. I knew I needed to teach him about behaving in public, about respecting others’ space and listening when I called his name. My heart pounded with the pressure to be a good mother, to guide him with patience and firmness. Just as I was about to kneel down and talk to him, my phone buzzed. It was Priya, an acquaintance from my building, asking if I could help her move some boxes into her new apartment—she sounded desperate, and I knew she didn’t have many people to rely on. I felt torn. I wanted to be there for her, to show kindness and support, but my son needed my attention right now. The expectations of being a responsible mother and a helpful acquaintance crashed together inside me, leaving me frozen in the cereal aisle, unsure which role to answer first.
